Amount: US$106.5 million Terms: Currency Pool Loan for 17 years, including 5 years grace, at the Bank's standard variable interest rate. Onlending: The proceeds of the loan directed toward gas distribution rehabilitation would be onlent to Volgograd Gorgas with an amortization period of 17 years, including 5 years grace. The energy efficiency component would be onlent to municipal district heating and power utilities with an amortization of 10 years, including 3 years grace. Funds onlent would carry an interest rate equal to the Bank lending rate plus a premium of 250 basis points. Objectives: The principal objectives of the project are to increase the efficiency of energy use in Russia, to improve the efficiency and safety of gas distribution, and to support policy reforms in the gas subsector. The project is expected to have both direct impact in the targeted cities and indirect impact elsewhere in Russia through the demonstration of technological and managerial principles. Description: The project consists of three components: (a) gas distribution network improvements; (b) energy efficiency investments; and (c) technical assistance. The gas distribution network investments largely focus on metering, cathodic protection, and pipe replacement. Energy efficiency investments would focus on replacement of outdated and inefficient equipment. Technical assistance is designed both to support project implementation and to advance the government's reform program. An initial program aimed at greenhouse gas reduction, and financed under the Global Environment Facility, is also linked to the project. Benefits: Direct project benefits arising through metering and through support of energy efficiency investments include opportunities to: (a) increase availability of low-cost gas for export; (b) defer investment in new gas supply; and/or, (c) displace petroleum products or coal in domestic markets, with resultant benefits in terms of environmental impacts and energy export opportunities. The investments in gas distribution rehabilitation would yield benefits in terms of increased economic life for network assets, as well as reduced investment costs through improved control and planning. The acquisition of leak detection equipment would also help to improve safety and reduce leakage of methane into the atmosphere. Risks: While it is expected that all project components would generate strong economic returns and acceptable financial returns, risks are not inconsiderable. Risks faced

THE MACROECONOMIC SETTING 1.1 Following the collapse of the former Soviet Union (FSU) in late 1991, the Russian government launched a radical program of economic reform to replace the remnants of the command economy with a market-oriented economy based on the private ownership of property. From the beginning, this effort took place in decidedly unfavorable conditions and, while results have been mixed, there have been significant achievements in a number of specific sectors. 1.2 A great deal was accomplished during the period 1992 - 1993 to move Russia toward a market economy. Prices have been liberalized, and there have been major shifts in relative prices, especially for the critical energy and service sectors. Privatization has led to a rapid transfer of state assets into private hands. Foreign trade has been substantially liberalized. Finally, enterprises are making decisions increasingly on the basis of commercial criteria. Macroeconomic problems have persisted, but can be largely traced to structural distortions that were inherited from the past. These distortions are being addressed and progress is being made in rectifying them, but full adjustment must be regarded as a long- term process. In the near term, various political factions are likely to express, and occasionally impose, alternative paths for development. However, it is expected that Russia will continue to move toward a market economy, both as a result of existing momentum, and for lack of a feasible alternative. 1.3 Within this evolving pattern of development, key sectors will have a direct positive impact at the macroeconomic and microeconomic level. Energy is one such sector, and within energy, the gas subsector is critical. Gas is the primary source of fuel in the domestic market, and in 1993 accounted for approximately 20 percent of foreign exchange earnings. The proposed Gas Distribution Rehabilitation and Energy Efficiency Project, the subject of this report, is consistent with the goals of sector and macroeconomic reform and recovery. The project would demonstrate the potential for short-term supply enhancements by improving the efficiency of gas utilization, while supporting Russia's sector-reform programs in the areas of price, structure, commercialization at the enterprise level, and reduced adverse environmental impact. II. THE ENERGY SECTOR 2.1 Energy is estimated to account for 15 percent of Russia's GDP, 11 percent of industrial production, and 50 percent of its convertible foreign exchange earnings. Rapid stabilization of the overall economy is unlikely to occur unless macroeconomic reforms are paralleled by energy- sector reform and recovery. A. Energy Resources, Production and Exports 2.2 It is estimated that Russia has 10 percent of the world's oil reserves, 33 percent of natural gas reserves, 10 percent of hard coal reserves, and 20 percent of the world's brown coal reserves. Its capacity to generate electric power ranks second in the world. Russia is the second largest energy producer in the world, accounting for about 14 percent of total commercial energy production. Despite
 - 2 - having one of the world's most energy intensive economies, Russia has been able to export over 25 percent of its total production, making it the largest exporter of energy. Energy exports, primarily of oil and gas, represent almost 50 percent of Russia's current exports to non-Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) countries, thus providing critical foreign exchange. 2.3 Maintaining productive capacity and developing unexploited energy reserves will require massive investments. Annual capital requirements for oil and gas alone, merely to stabilize existing production levels, are probably in the excess of US$10 billion. Funds are no longer available to meet these requirements, however; and the future prospects for the sector are grim. Output of energy is now falling in all energy subsectors. Crude oil output is down more than 45 percent from its 1988 peak and has been declining at an annual rate of about 15 percent for the past three years. This decline must be viewed as catastrophic if sustained for another year or two. Natural gas production, which had steadily increased over the past several years, declined by over 3 percent 1993, and is estimated to have fallen by a similar percentage in 1994. Production of coal has also been declining by approximately 10 percent each year, indicating a deepening crisis in this subsector as well. Finally, Russia's electricity-generating capacity has only been adequate owing to a drop in consumption of about 6 percent per year. Without this contraction in demand, the poorly maintained power plants and ageing asset base would be inadequate. Data on Russia's energy production and net exports for the years 1990 to 1993 are contained in Annex 2-1. 2.4 Energy exports in 1993 consisted of: natural gas, estimated at 51 percent; oil and petroleum products, 42 percent; coal, 5 percent; and electricity, 2 percent (based on tons of oil equivalence). Natural gas is expected to become increasingly important, in both export and domestic markets, because of its environmental attractiveness. As a result, the strategic value of gas to the Russian economy requires special attention. B. Energy Consumption 2.5 Data on consumption of commercial energy in Russia for 1990 through 1993 are presented, by type, in Annex 2-1. Energy consumption decreased by 12 percent between 1990 and 1993, from 1,121 million tons of oil equivalent (mtoe) to 984 mtoe. The largest declines were in the coal sector (23 percent) and petroleum products (32 percent). Gas consumption remained relatively constant during this period (as interfuel substitution has taken place in the interim). In 1993, gas accounted for about 55 percent of domestic consumption', petroleum about 18 percent and coal 17 percent. The remaining 10 percent was largely primary electricity supply (nuclear and hydroelectric power). While gas volumes were down in 1993 relative to 1990, the share was 6 percentage points higher. The prospects for continued increases in market share for natural gas are good because of its relative price advantages and favorable environmental impacts. 2.6 Inefficient energy use is prevalent throughout the Russian economy. In 1992, Russia's energy use per unit of GDP was 14 times that of Japan, 8 times that of the United Kingdom, and 5 times that of the United States. This problem has since worsened, with considerable decreases in economic output and only modest decreases in energy consumption. Russia's inefficient energy use stems from a combination of factors, including an emphasis on energy-intensive industries, widespread use of inefficient and outdated equipment, prices that discourage efficient use of energy, and an absence of metering.  - 3 - 2.7 The potential for the economic rationalization of energy consumption in Russia is substantial. The government has initiated a program of reforms to address this prospect encompassing: (a) energy price adjustments, through liberalization of pricing mechanisms, reduction in subsidies and reduction in export constraints; (b) preparation of draft legislation on energy conservation; and, (c) establishment of the Russian Energy Savings Foundation (RESF) to encourage energy efficiency investments. C. Energy Prices, Taxes, and Subsidies 2.8 Significant adjustments have been made to relative energy prices over the past three to four years. In 1991 energy prices were less than 10 percent of estimated market levels. By early 1995, domestic gas prices to industrial and commercial customers had reached approximately two-thirds of estimated full cost recovery, and domestic prices for petroleum products were at similar levels. Electricity prices varied among regions, but were typically around 60 percent of full cost recovery on sales to industry. Energy prices to households, however, have risen at a more gradual rate. The government has justified the slower increase in household prices in light of the slow adjustment in labor prices, the absence of an effective safety net and the resultant concerns over household ability-to-pay for energy. Given that the poor typically spend a disproportionate share of their income on energy, this approach is acceptable until an adequate safety net is established. 2.9 Taxation of oil production has been prohibitive. This policy has resulted in financial losses by producing enterprises, and sharply curtailed investment. Petroleum tax rates are very high, and, since they are based on revenues rather than profits, are insensitive to the variations in production and operating costs across the sector. Financial support has been extended to the sectcr through direct budget transfers, as is the case for coal, or through subsidized credits, which have been granted to the oil and gas subsectors. Overall, there is a pressing need to continue to rationalize energy prices and reform taxes; however, these policies entail far-reaching macroeconomic and structural implications. Recent actions on tax reforms and reductions in subsidized credit have improved the situation considerably. D. Energy and the Environment 2.10 Russia's current environmental problems are serious and widespread, and result from past policies that set performance targets in quantitative terms and did not place an economic value on the environment, lack of environmental legislation, standards and management systems, and pricing policies that undervalued natural resources. Russia's energy inefficiency, in both production and end-use, not only accelerates the depletion of economic resources, but also represents a prime cause of pollution and of natural resource degradation. Price reform, coupled with investment in more efficient technologies, would help to correct this problem, and the government is therefore actively pursuing initiative in both of these areas. Furthermore, environmental legislation is being steadily improved, both in terms of establishing standards and enforcing their implementation. E. Organization of the Energy Sector and Structural Reform 2.11 Prior to 1990, energy was fully integrated into the FSU's national plan. The sector was managed by central government ministries and by subsector or branch ministries. This centralization of authority, together with the lack of coordination among those central ministries with authority over energy subsectors, stifled commercial and operational initiatives in the sector and led to the pressure to decentralize.
 - 4 - 2.12 Russia's energy sector is undergoing structural reform to ameliorate these problems. Goals of the reform package include reduced state intervention, the promotion of competition, and a strong, independent private sector. Since 1991, progress has been made regarding each of these objectives. While policy matters remain under the jurisdiction of the ministries, branch ministries were converted to large state-owned enterprises, which were to address commercial and operational matters for each subsector. The new enterprises included: Rosneftegas, with jurisdiction over crude oil production; Glavtransneft, crude oil transport; Rosnefteproduct, oil product transport and distribution; Gazprom, non- associated gas production, transmission, storage and export; Rosstrojgasifikazia, gas distribution2; Ugol Rossii, coal; and Rossenergo, electric power. Although distanced from the ministries, these state or national concerns were wholly owned by the state and were still formally accountable to them. Selected activities came under newly established committees rather than state concerns; for example, oil refining under the Refining Committee within the Ministry of Fuel and Power, and oil exploration under the State Committee on Geology (the former Ministry of Geology). 2.13 Following the creation of the state concerns, a period of further decentralization of control over the sector began, which was fostered by certain parts of the reform movement in Government that promoted competition. Other factions in the government, however, regarded this development as potentially disruptive during a time when stability in energy supplies was vital, and thus argued for a slowdown to the decentralization process. By and large, the Government has acceded to the latter proposal. 2.14 As of the present, all of the state energy enterprises have been converted into joint stock companies (JSC's). This is beneficial in that it sets the stage for corporatization of the enterprises along coommercial lines and for their ultimate privatization. At the same time, a controlling interest in each of the new JSCs is to be retained by the state. For the most part, administrative responsibility for the state's shareholdings has been placed in the hands of a few centralized holding companies, which are themselves either wholly owned or effectively controlled by the state. Privatization has entered a new phase in which the government intends to sell its remaining equity stake in profitable enterprises at a price that would provide a reasonable return on its original investment. This project is designed to further this objective (see para 6.8). F. Foreign Direct Investment 2.15 Foreign direct investment in Russia's energy sector can make a critical difference: in funding; in transferring technology; in promoting a competitive environment; and in transferring managerial skills appropriate to a market economy. To date, however, the energy sector, like the rest of the economy, has had little success in attracting major foreign investment. Investors have attributed this to the absence of an accommodating legal and fiscal framework, to institutional uncertainties, and to understandable confusions during a period of major transition. An important factor often mentioned by potential foreign investors in the energy sector is the conflicting signals they receive from Russia; in the end, the investors are not persuaded that their investments are welcomed. 2/ With the exception of Moscow and St. Petersburg, which were the responsibility of Mosgas and Lengas, respectively.

Bank's Role in the Energy Sector 2.16 The Bank's energy strategy in Russia has been to support sector reform and recovery through direct assistance to the Russian authorities in designing their reform program and in developing a focused program of energy lending. The Bank assigned high priority to the oil and gas subsectors owing to: (a) the potential to attract significant inflow of foreign investment capital; (b) their potential to generate foreign exchange through exports; (c) the potential impact on the fiscal deficit through adjustment of domestic prices and rationalization of taxes; and, (d) the prospect of an early impact on sector revenues and export earnings. 2.17 Identification of suitable projects for lending has proceeded in parallel with technical cooperation. The US$1 billion project to support urgently required oil production rehabilitation in western Siberia is effective and procurement is advancing favorably. A second oil production rehabilitation project has also been approved for which procurement is well advanced. Other projects in the oil subsector have been identified including: (a) a joint venture for new field development; (b) a refinery restructuring investment; and, (c) oil transport. In the gas sector, Gazprom, the entity responsible for production and transmission, has been able to attract financing from other sources, leaving the Bank to focus on gas distribution and energy efficiency investments. 2.18 The Bank has broadened its energy sector dialogue with the government to include other subsectors, such as power and coal.3 Lending to the energy sector could range between US$500 million and US$1 billion annually for the next several years. As indicated in the most recent Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), the energy sector is expected to be a major focus of Bank lending, accounting for roughly 40 percent of new commitments during the FY93-97 period. In particular, the CAS recognizes that developments in the energy sector are critical to Russia's export prospects over the next several years and therefore to the viability of the external financing program. In all cases, the highest priority would be assigned to designing a lending program that would act as a catalyst to private sector investment. Once the macroeconomic framework stabilizes and an acceptable investment framework has been established, the Bank's relative role in Russia's energy sector should decline significantly, giving way to private funding. The proposed Project is fully consistent with the Bank's policy objectives in the recent CAS and represents a priority use of Bank resources in assisting the transformation of the Russian economy. 111. GAS SUBSECTOR A. Gas Resources, Production and Exports 3.1 As of the beginning of 1993, Russia's gas reserves were estimated at 48 trillion cubic meters, 33 percent of l; e world's reserves. Gas production was 617 billion cubic meters (BCM) in 1993, down 3.5 percent from 1992, giving a reserve-to-production ratio of 78 years. The majority of production takes place in western Siberia: in 1992, the Urenguoy field produced 288 BCM and Yamburg produced 178 BCM. Although associated gas production has typically been about 6 percent of total gas production, it is estimated that a further 3 percent could be recovered by recapturing flared gas. In 1993, gas exports from Russia included 65 BCM to Western Europe, and 36 BCM to Central Europe. Russian gas accounts for 90 percent of the total with the remaining 10 percent transited through Russia from Turkmenistan. 3/ A portion of the Bank's first technical cooperation project (TCP) in Russia, approved by the Bank's Board of Directors in September 1992, was allocated to coal.

Exports to cther FSU republics, however, fell by approximately 25 percent (from 106 BCM to 79 BCM), mainly owing to economic restructuring and payment problems. The Yamburg field alone has the potential to deliver another 60 to 80 BCM/yr, roughly equivalent to the level of Russia's current exports to Western Europe. Step-outs from the existing fields will also keep the cost of gas supply low for the near to medium term. Russia's large unexploited fields (Yamal and Shtokmanskaya in the Barents Sea) are remote and present considerable environmental problems. Postponing the need to mobilize these resources would enable Gazprom to further address the environmental problems associated with the new fields. B. Natural Gas Demand 3.3 Export Markets: Although the export market during the early 1990's has been relatively weak, gas demand outside Russia is expected to rise in the medium to long term. Forecasts of exports of Russian gas prepared in 1992 indicated an 8 percent overall decline between 1992 and 1994, with a gradual levelling off and beginning recovery after 1997. The decline was dominated by a sharp drop in exports to FSU countries. (see table in Annex 3-1). Preliminary 1994 data indicate continued growth in gas markets in Central Europe, and a slower but steady increase in Western European demand. Markets in the FSU countries remain weak, however. Russia is a major source of natural gas for Central and Western European markets, and is viewed as the single most important source for future gas supplies. Alternative sources of gas, which include Algeria, Iran, the North Sea, and the Central Asian Republics, each face transit problems. Russia, however, has the potential to supply a significant portion of the expected growth in European gas markets, and at competitive prices, as low-cost gas becomes available from the rationalization of existing domestic markets and the capture of flared associated gas. Assuming sufficient transmission capacity, Russia could expect not only to maintain but also to increase its share in the European markets. Indications are, however, that transmission capacity may be a growing constraint. The main transit route is through the Ukraine, and there are continued allegations that the Ukraine is appropriating transit gas for its own use, in order to make up for Russian cutbacks in deliveries to Ukraine as a result of payment arrears. Alternative routes through Poland/Belarus are being explored, and would require in the order of US$5 billion in investment. At present, however, the financing and the international ownership/operating agreements needed to develop this corridor are not yet in place. 3.4 Domestic Market: Gas has been capturing an increasing share of the primary energy market in Russia, displacing coal in the 1970s and petroleum products in the late 1980s. With coal and oil production decreasing, gas continues to increase market share, nearing half of Russia's total primary consumption. This trend is expected to continue as gas-based power generation increases, both for cost and environmental reasons. C. Gas Balance 3.9 In general, the government has strongly supported gas exports both because of the higher net-backs and the access to foreign exchange. As a result, gas is supply-constrained in Russia during the peak winter months. This situation is expected to change considerably in the near to medium term as both export and domestic markets evolve. Gas availability is expected to increase as a result of the collapse in the markets of the FSU. This would lead to Russia's gas supply becoming demand- constrained in the foreseeable future (see Annex 3-1), a situation that has already been manifested in the summers of 1993 and 1994, when Gazprom was unable to find markets for gas that was available for production. Hence, it is expected that many of the gas-supply projects that are planned for the late 1990s will be deferred, and Gazprom will start to develop enhanced supply to the domestic market, including gas storage to help meet winter peaks. D. Institutional Setting 3.10 Gazprom: Gazprom dominates the natural gas industry in Russia. Its monopoly on non-associated gas production, gas transmission, storage and gas exports makes it the largest gas company in the world. In addition, through the system of gas allocation, it strongly influences the Russian gas market. The scale of Gazprom's operations, its financial strength, its control over domestic gas supply, and its access to 'oreign currency, combine to make it a dominant entity within the energy sector. Its contribution to economic stability in a turbulent period of economic restructuring is an important and well recognized factor. Project Objectives 6.1 The principal objectives of the project are: (a) to increase the efficiency of gas use within Russia by upgrading and increasing the use of customer metering and by supporting investments in more efficient equipment; (b) to reduce gas distribution costs, and maintain distribution system capacity and integrity, through network rehabilitation; and, (c) to support the government's reform program through technical assistance. The objectives will be realized both directly through project-financed investments and indirectly through demonstration impacts. 6.2 More efficient use of gas will increase the availability of energy for export, either by increasing the supply of exportable gas from existing fields, or by making gas available to replace domestic use of other fuels, thereby freeing up other energy products for export. Increased gas exports will increase financial flows to the government, which currently captures approximately 30 percent of the export value. Increased energy efficiency will reduce the operating costs of domestic gas users, thus increasing their competitiveness and potentially reducing the inter-agency arrears problem. Increasing the efficiency of gas use will also have a beneficial effect on the environment, both directly through decreased emissions, and indirectly by enabling increased substitution of gas for fuels that have a less favorable environmental impact. B. Project Description 6.3 The project was prepared by Volgograd Gorgas and RESF, with the assistance of USAID- financed consultants. The project includes three main components, each of which comprises several sub- components. The components are: (a) rehabilitation of gas distribution systems; (b) energy efficiency investments; and, (c) technical assistance to support the government's reform program and project implementation. In addition, a companion Global Environment Facility (GEF) project will support initiatives aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions including financing a portion of the leak detection sub-component. New meters will be installed at unmetered commercial enterprises, households, and apartment blocks. Pilot schemes undertaken elsewhere in Russia have reportedly resulted in decreases in gas consumption which range from 25 to 50 percent. The replacement of outdated industrial and commercial meters will bring about improved accuracy in recording consumption. The principle upon which gas pricing recommendations are based is its market value. To establish this, some understanding of the market for Russia gas production is necessary. Briefly, its export markets to western Europe are about 60 BCM/year. This is forecast to grow at about 3% p.a. Over the long term energy consumption in central Europe is still being rationalized, and demand has generally been dropping with some notable exceptions -- gas demand has increased in Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic in 1993. Thus gas exports to central Europe are expected to remain constant over the near term (as some countries pull out of their recession and growth starts), followed by a strong increase in demand growth (to about 5% p.a.). Russian gas is expected to capture much of this incremental demand as it is the least cost fuel for many markets. Exports to the FSU (particularly Ukraine) are expected to contract considerably as prices increase and the structure of the economies evolve. 2. Russian demand is also expected to contract considerably, largely as a result of three phenomena: (i) shutting down uneconomic plants and scaling back production due to market contraction; (ii) energy conservation in industries that survive; and (iii) a change in the structure in the economy (away from heavy industry and toward light industry and services) resulting in new investments using technologies that are energy efficient. Pricing Principles 3. Industrial Sector (all but households): The reduction in gas consumption has resulted in a situation in which gas is demand constrained. In a liberalized energy market, in which independent gas producers would compete for market share, gas supply would compete for market share with gas from other sources (rather than petroleum products). Under such a scenario, gas prices would approach the cost of supply (as has been the case in United States) rather than petroleum product equivalents. Over the near term, the short run marginal cost of supply would reflect maintenance investments (as expansion needs are expected to be limited over the near- to medium-term) in the existing system, resulting in a low marginal cost of supply. 4. As gas companies in the FSU are privatized, the financial cost of supply has become the primary consideration in price setting. These utilities need prices to be set at sufficient levels to enable them to cover their operating and maintenance costs and most of their investment costs due to the linited access to capital. To establish the appropriate pricing signals (to provide an incentive for energy efficiency investments and to enable new investments in downstream sectors to be based on an economically efficient mix of labor, capital and energy), gas prices should reflect the full cost of supply (based on a reasonable rate of return on revalued assets). It is important that prices are not simply increased to this level, as this could result in generating excess cash for gas utilities, which would likely result in (unearned) dividends to the shareholders (resulting in an undesirable transfer of wealth from gas consumers to gas company employees). Given that the Government budget was the source of financing for these investments, it is appropriate that the returns on these investments should be directed to the Government. This can be accomplished by anyone of a number of financial instruments including by imposing an excise tax which will enable the Government to receive a return on its equity and thus help
 -53- Annex 3-3 Page 2 of 2 mitigate the fiscal deficit problem. This tax should be an interim measure that is gradually replaced by corporate taxes as gas utilities start to replace the Government as the investor in the system's assets. Gas prices would need to be increased to enable the gas utilities to finance part of their investments from internally generated funds and to service a growing debt load. By taking Govermnent rent through corporate taxes, incentives would also be established for corporate entities in the gas sector to improve efficiency. 5. In addition, gas should be sold at the "city gate" (or plant gate) at a price that reflects the cost of extraction and delivery, and hence should be differentiated by region. Prices should also reflect the seasonal variations in the cost of supply, explicitly valuing storage costs. (Gas supply during the winter months is currently constrained by inadequate storage. Storage facilities need to be mobilized to enable gas to capture more of the current market currently serviced by petroleum products. 6. Using typical international gas equipment costs as a proxy to value Russia's gas system assets (as the current book costs suffer numerous distortions), it has been estimated that the cost of supply to the city gate in the Moscow region is about US$30 to US$35/MCM. Incremental supply costs to industries in Russia have been much lower than other countries because the customer carries much of the incremental investment costs. Hence, the total supply cost to industrial customers in the Moscow region is estimated to be about US$35-US$40/MCM. Gas prices as of April 1995 are about 60-70 percent of this target. 7. Sales to Households: Gas prices for households would have to be increased by about 20-fold (over the March 1995 levels) to reflect the full (replacement) cost of supply. However, since much of the asset base is fully amortized and maintenance costs are low, March 1995 prices are estimated to cover about 10% of the current cost of supply. With current income levels, increasing gas prices to fully recover costs is clearly not feasible, since utility costs would exceed many households total income. This problem can be addressed in one of three ways: (i) gas prices to households can be increased gradually, while the difference between the financial cost of supply and the price charged to households is covered by cross-subsidies from industrial consumption; (ii) gas prices to households could be increased gradually as in (i), while the difference between the cost of supply and the price charged is explicitly identified and financed from a Government budget transfer; or, (iii) gas prices could be increased to reflect the full cost of supply and the customers would receive a cash transfer from the Government through a social safety net to help pay for this increased cost. 8. The advantage of the first option is that it is easy to implement and has a low administrative cost. The disadvantage is that the incentive for households to conserve energy is relatively low, and that the existing price distortion is addressed by introducing another price distortion. When this approach has been used elsewhere, these distortions are usually retained for a longer period of time than is desirable. The advantage of (ii) over (i) is that the price distortion to industries is avoided. However, experience elsewhere indicates that these budget transfers are either slow in coming or aren't paid at all. (A good example of this is the case of pensioners in Russia who receive gas at a 50 percent discount, while the remaining 50 percent is expected to be paid by the municipality. Gas distribution companies complain that this payment has not been forthcoming.) Option (ii) also suffers from an increased administrative cost over option (i). The advantage of option (iii) is that all prices reflect their economic cost, providing the consumer with appropriate incentives (households could profit considerably from adjusting their consumption). However, it is administratively burdensome and difficult to implement. Therefore, the recommended gas price strategy for households is to increase these prices gradually, while maintaining financial viability for utilities through cross-subsidies if necessary. Background The process of transforming local GDCs in Russia into joint stock companies was initiated by Presidential Decree in December 1992 and is now well advanced. Final clearance of each individual organization's proposals has been given for about 50 percent of all the utilities by August 1993 and the remainder are expected to be approved by November. Allocation of shares follows shortly after approval with employees of an enterprises owning either 40 percent or 51 percent, depending on the variant chosen. The remaining shares will be held for the next 3 years by various municipal and state bodies, after which a decision will be made on further disposals. Or2anization The Board of Directors of the new companies will initially comprise the General Director of the company, representatives of municipal and state bodies and a Trade Union representative. Internally, companies will probably follow existing practice, using a Management Board comprising the General Director, Deputy Directors and up to 5-10 Heads of Departments. Employee numbers range from a few hundred in the smaller city companies up to several thousand in the larger city and regional companies. Typically, they are organized into 3 main functional groups - engineering (employing the great majority), economic and financial (mainly billing and bookkeeping) and general administrative services (stores and buildings). Training Requirements Six gas distribution companies (Ryazan, Voronezh, Volgograd, Saratov, Stavropol and Rostov-on-the Don) have been visited by World Bank missions to prepare the proposed Gas Distribution Reconstruction and Energy Efficiency Project. These missions have concluded that the senior management of the companies need to upgrade their skills to enable them to manage their new business entities in a commercial environment. They appear to be proceeding on the assumption that their present organizational structure will continue to be appropriate and that management issues and practices will be little changed. This is understandable in the light of the many other urgent problems that they have had to handle over the last year, but does not provide a good basis for taking advantage of their new status. Managers in the GDCs will in fact need to adapt rapidly to a changing environment, and to take responsibility for their business strategies and decisions. In these new circumstances, there are many

This is not to doubt that the staff have the capacity to acquire these skills but, up to now, there have been no means for them to do so. Senior managers in all the utilities visited regret that they have had little or no opportunity for contacts with their counterparts in gas utilities operating abroad. They are particularly concerned about this in respect of engineering developments and are less focused on the gap in management practices because of the lack of familiarity with business management in a market economy. However, there is a general awareness of the need to develop new skills and there is no doubt that initiatives to meet this need would be welcomed. Such institutional reform and development would require staff at a range of different levels to be trained to understand more fully the demands placed on an investor-owned company in a market economy, and to acquire the professional expertise that is necessary to meet these demands. The scope for training is, therefore, considerable, both in the range of topics to be covered and in the number of managers within each company who would benefit. In view of the urgency of initiating comprehensive training arrangements, it is desirable to proceed simultaneously on a number of fronts. For example, training should be provided in parallel both for the top management and for middle-management. A good grounding in business management practices for top managers will pay off quickly only if trained supporting staff are available to implement the new procedures. Conversely, training middle-management specialists in modern techniques could lead to disillusion and cynicism if top management is then not receptive and eager to use these techniques in its decision-making. The specialist areas that should be covered include business planning, accounting and finance, investment appraisal, systems development (including use of computers), sales and marketing, procurement, personnel management, shareholder services and efficiency improvement. Some technical training may be provided by consultants and contractors as part of reconstruction and energy efficiency projects but more comprehensive training in modern gas distribution engineering practices is also desirable. These areas are set out in more detail in the Annex. For the most senior management in each company more general training should be provided on managing a joint stock company, including accountability to a Board of Directors and shareholders. Senior managers also require a broad initiation into the more specialist areas so that they can be aware of their potential benefits and properly manage the newly-trained staff. Length and Character of Training Management and technical skills cannot be acquired overnight and theoretical classroom training is of limited value. To meet the objectives outlined above, a significant number of employees in each GDC should spend a period of at least three months, and preferably six months, working in a gas distribution utility abroad. Experience has shown (particularly the technical assistance component of the Marshall Plan) that on-the-job training of this kind is effective in communicating both theoretical and practical knowledge, while stimulating enthusiasm and a desire to exercise the new skills. It is important, however, to recognize that the trainee must have acquired a working knowledge of the language of the host country before embarking on the training process. It would be impractical to provide an interpreter with each trainee and much of value would be lost if language were a serious obstacle. Trainees should, therefore, receive adequate language training before travel and the cost should be included in the financial

For the most senior management in each company, it is unlikely that personnel could be absent for an extended period or that they would be able quickly to acquire a new language skill. Training for this group, therefore, should take the form of shorter courses and seminars covering general management at which interpreters would be available. Organization of Training The desirable emphasis of on-the-job training, coupled with the significant number of staff to be included from each GDC, strongly suggests that such training would most effectively be organized within a "twinning" arrangement. A Russian GDC would be linked with a similar company in North America or Western Europe on a continuing basis, providing benefits over a long period. In the initial two years, some 4-6 individuals (depending on the size of the GDC) would spend six months with the host company, the arrangement to be repeated four times. The advantage of this approach is that it would not overly tax the host GDC and would provide an opportunity to reinforce new skills as each team returns (there is a danger that the skills will be lost if periodic reinforcement isn't established). The Russian and the host companies would each appoint a co-ordinating officer who would set up the necessary arrangements, monitor the progress of the trainees and develop the program in the light of experience. The program should be intensive, with readily identifiable deliverables for each team. Towards the end of the initial two-year period, the further training needs of the Russian GDC would be jointly reviewed and a continuing program developed. A preliminary estimate of the cost of such a program suggests, that the direct cost of sending an individual to a foreign utility for a six-month period could be US$25,000 with a similar sum incurred by the host utility in providing the facilities. For a group of six individuals repeated four times over a two-year, the total would be US$1 .2m per company. In addition, the arrangements for short-term visits and seminars for training senior management would cost a further US$0.4m. Conclusion A twinning arrangement between a Russian GDC and a foreign utility would provide an effective means of organizing urgently needed business, professional and technical training for middle and senior management. Gas Distribution Component The network improvements component of the project will be implemented over four calendar years, starting in the third quarter of 1995 through the second quarter of 1999. A project director will head the team and be supported by discipline coordinators. The key discipline coordinators required will be engineering, procurement, planning and controls, construction and installation, quality assurance and administration. Considering the high educational level of the GDC senior staff and their understanding of the problems faced by the companies, the preferred option would be to assign senior staff to the project from within the GDC organisation, with the chief engineer of the GDC taking the position of project director. The following describes the principal responsibilities for the key personnel. Project Director: The project director will have overall responsibility for the implementation of the project. The director will report to the general manager of the GDC and have the following primary objectives: i) to complete the project on schedule and within the agreed budget; ii) to ensure that the quality, safety and environmental standards agreed for the project are understood and adhered to; iii) to ensure that all documentation and reports are prepared on time and filed accordingly; and iv) to ensure that the implementation team functions as an effective and cohesive group. Engineering Coordinator: The engineering coordinator will have responsibility for all aspects of the engineering including finalizing the technical specifications for procurement, completing the detailed engineering required for the project and preparing detailed installation procedures, drawings, schedules and plans. Procurement Coordinator: The procurement coordinator will be responsible for all aspects of local and international procurement including issuing procurement notices, finalizing bid packages, issuing bids, receiving proposals, supervising bid openings, evaluations and evaluation reports, preparing and issuing purchase contracts. doc.repnme: Russian Federation - Gas Distribution Rehabilitation and Energy Efficiency Project
doc.abstracts: The Gas Distribution Rehabilitation and Energy Efficiency Project will increase the efficiency of energy use in Russia, will improve the efficiency and safety of gas distribution, and will support policy reforms in the gas subsector. The project is expected to have both direct impact in the targeted cities and indirect impact elsewhere in Russia through the demonstration of technological and managerial principles. The project consists of three components: (a) gas distribution network improvements; (b) energy efficiency investments; and (c) technical assistance. The gas distribution network investments largely focus on metering, cathodic protection, and pipe replacement. Energy efficiency investment will focus on replacement of outdated and inefficient equipment. Technical assistance is designed both will support project implementation and to advance the government's reform program. An initial program aimed at greenhouse gas reduction, and financed under the Global Environment Facility, is also linked to the project.
